results.title: River Rhine
results.brief_description: The Rhine is studied in four sections - from the source to Basel, Basel to Bingen, Bingen to Bonn and from Bonn to the mouth at Europoort. The agriculture and industries of each section are shown, together with the use of the river for transportation. The recent building of the Grand Canal d’Alsace is also seen.

results.title: River people of Chad
results.creator_credit: Institut für Film und Bild and Visual Education Centre (Germany)
results.brief_description: An adaptation of the film made by the Instutut fur Film und Bild, Munich. Contrasts the modern city of Fort Lamy with the villages of Chad, where men, women and children use primitive tools for farming, fishing and cooking in a communal environment.

results.title: River of steel
results.creator_credit: Peter Sachs, Film Producers Guild and W H Larkin Cartoon Studio
results.brief_description: A short cartoon summary of steel making followed by a humorous glimpse of a world suddenly deprived of its steel. A rhyming commentary guides through the processing of the steel, which is conveyed pictorially by bold attempts to combine the utilitarian approach of the drawing office and the artistic licence of the abstract painter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Sachs, Film Producers Guild and W H Larkin Cartoon Studio

results.title: River of life
results.creator_credit: John Taylor, Ralph Keene and Independent Artists (GB)
results.brief_description: Changing moods of the Welsh River Usk followed through the seasons of the year. Delicate camera-work reveals activities, rare to the naked eye, of species living in and around the river - the microscopic diatoms and leeches, insects, birds and fish - all contributing to the intricate society of the river’s life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Taylor, Ralph Keene and Independent Artists (GB)

results.title: River of hope
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The Damodar Valley Project. The Damodar River in Dihar is known as the River of Sorrow; during the monsoon its floods cause death and destruction on a gigantic scale. The Damodar Valley Project is combating this with a series of dams on the river and its tributaries, and a barrage across the confluence of the Damodar and the Barakar Rivers.

results.title: River of diamonds
results.creator_credit: Antony Thomas, J. Blake Dalrymple and Films of Africa
results.brief_description: Gives the colorful history of the Orange River, lifeblood of half of South Africa’s cities in the east and its farms in the west. We see the mountains where the river rises, the farms and cities along its course, with the dams and tunnels now changing its face. Diamond mining has been the major industry since diamonds were discovered in 1866; now underwater drilling has commenced where the Orange enters the sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Antony Thomas, J. Blake Dalrymple and Films of Africa

results.title: River journey on the Upper Nile
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: Examines the Upper Nile from Malakal to Juba in the Sudan. Describes the Shilluk and Dinka peoples of the region and how they are unable to produce enough food to subsist and are forced to acquire additional supplies from Juba. The film follows the journey made down the Nile River to Juba during the rainy season and shows the conditions of the regions which the river flows through.

results.title: Ritual: the collective psyche of Japan
results.brief_description: A Kaleidoscope of images of Japan, filmed mainly in Tokyo. The film shows a way of life based on rituals - community rituals, rituals of work and play, the psychic rituals of Zen and the martial rituals of the Samurai.
results.description: A Kaleidoscope of images of Japan, filmed mainly in Tokyo. The film shows a way of life based on rituals - community rituals, rituals of work and play, the psychic rituals of Zen and the martial rituals of the Samurai.

results.title: Risks and routines
results.creator_credit: Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Aimed at carers in Community Residential Units (CRU), this short program provides practical advice on how to care for epilepsy sufferers. It outlines the importance of record keeping, routine, medication maintenance, treatment for status epilepticus and the recognition of independence. Features “Barry” (performed by Doug Pentland) a CRU resident and drawings by Dorothy Berry, as well as comments from epilepsy sufferers who explain what it feels like to have a seizure and what can trigger an attack. Contains footage of a tonic clonic seizure. Please note this video is not intended to function as a formal training guide and doesn’t contain a manual as stated on the tape.
